Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop accurate and robust ultrahigh temperature microsensors for in situ measurement of heat-flux and dynamic pressure inside turbine engines for power generation and aircraft propulsion. The proposed sensors are based on a new class of high-temperature multifunctional materials recently developed in PIs? laboratory at University of Central Florida (UCF). The materials, named Polymer-Derived Ceramics (PDCs), possess a unique combination of excellent high-temperature durability, micromachinable capability, and tunable electronic properties, thus suitable for harsh environmental applications. In order to develop the necessary knowledge base, which will lead to the successful development of novel high temperature microsensors and sensing systems for turbine engine systems, the following research tasks will be performed within this three-year project: (i) developing capability for fine tuning the electronic properties of PDCs, (ii) optimally determining micromachining conditions for PDC sensors; (iii) modeling, designing and fabricating heat-flux sensor and dynamic pressure sensor; and (iv) characterizing the performance and high-temperature stability of the fabricated sensor.

The proposed research will be conducted by an interdisciplinary team consisting of expertise in the fields of materials science, micromachining, and sensor design/characterization. Experts from related local industries will also be involved in sensor performance evaluation

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the proposed research is to develop high-temperature sensors for in-situ and on-line monitoring turbine engines. To achieve this overall objective, the proposed research has following specific scientific goals: (i) developing capabilities for fine tuning electric properties of PDCs; (ii) developing/optimizing micromachining procedures for PDCs; and (iii) designing, fabricating and characterizing a set of sensors.

We have demonstrated that by adding different amounts of poly(melamine-co-formaldehyde) acrylated (PVN) into the polymeric precursor, we can significantly change the conductivity of the resultant ceramics to meet the requirements of sensors. We have also demonstrated that by using a 5-aix micro-milling system, the materials can be machined into microstructures with fine structural dimensions and high aspect ratios. By using the material, we designed, fabricated, and tested two sensors: temperature sensor and pressure sensor. Both of the sensors were based on a simple two-arm circuit design to convert the change in resistance to that in voltage for complying with commercially available data acquisition units. The suitable shunt resistor was simulated and selected to achieve optimal sensitivity. We finally characterized the sensors and demonstrated that both of the sensor exhibited very high sensitivity and excellent repeatability.  

The project has supported four graduate students; two of them are females. The PIs and students have published several papers in prestigious journals and delivered a few invited talks and presentations at national/international conferences. The research findings have also been incorporated into a graduate course at UCF.
